context: In most parts of medieval Europe, <a0_0>the <a5_0>upper class<a5_0/><a0_0/> obtained the sole rights to <b10_0>hunt<b10_0/> in certain areas of a feudal territory. Game in these areas was used as a source of <a1_0><a6_0>food and furs<a6_0/><a1_0/>, often provided via <a7_0><b12_0>professional<b12_0/> huntsmen<a7_0/>, but it was also expected to provide a form of <b13_0>recreation<b13_0/> for the aristocracy. The importance of this proprietary view of game can be seen in the <a2_0><a8_0><b14_0>Robin Hood<b14_0/><a8_0/><a2_0/> legends, in which one of the primary charges against the outlaws is that <a3_0>they "hunt the King's deer<a3_0/>". In contrast, settlers in Anglophone colonies gloried <a4_0>democratically in <b11_0>hunting<b11_0/> for <a9_0>all<a9_0/><a4_0/>.
